revision.text:
{{BLP primary sources|date=June 2010}} '''Victor Alfred Cornelius Eustace Beltane Diggory Penrith Pratt''' more commonly known as '''Vic Pratt''' is an artist, writer, musician and actor born in 1971. He lives in [[Muswell Hill]], North East London.<ref>Biography in ''The Zine'' #9</ref>
Pratt printed two issues of his own [[British small press comics]] ''Flea Circus''<ref>flea circus website http://www.fortunecity.co.uk/southbank/pottery/768/index.html</ref> in the mid-1990s. His comic strips are mostly autobiographical similar to [[Robert Crumb]] or [[Chester Brown]]. His art influences are [[David Law]] and [[Hergé]]. He drew a comic strip "Bad Feedback" in which he remembers his time in university having his comics rejected.
He wrote reviews in the 1990s small press [[zine]] ''Zum!''<ref>website at http://www.zumcomics.info/</ref> He also wrote for ''[[Story Paper Collectors' Digest]]'', a magazine about British boys' [[story paper]] fiction. He wrote reports on "The Old Boys' Bookclub". Pratt is a historian on [[British comics]] and wrote reviews and drew comics in ''[[Psychopia]]'' the zine of British comics. He drew many multi artist "jam strips" in the zine including "Martian Jam" and "Stranded on the M25".
As the [[British Film Institute]] fiction film curator he brought the first screening of [[Stanley Long]]'s ''Primitive London'' film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.resonancefm.com/listings/20070127.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=February 2, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070219035038/http://www.resonancefm.com/listings/20070127.html |archivedate=February 19, 2007 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.fayrstede.com/news3.htm Fayrestede Productions Ltd - The Homepage of Stanley Long]</ref> He brought to the National Film Theatre the first screening of the live-action ''[[The Adventures of Tintin]]'' film ''Tintin and the Golden Treasure''.<ref>[http://forbiddenplanet.co.uk/blog/?p=3003 The Forbidden Planet International Blog Log » Tintin at the NFT]</ref> As National Film Archive curator he introduces [[Rupert Bear]] Night with special guests [[Mary Turner]] creator of the puppet show and [[Terry Jones]] ([[Monty Python]]).<ref>[http://www.bfi.org.uk/whatson/bfi_southbank/events/rupert_bear_night Rupert Bear Night | What's On] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220231538/http://www.bfi.org.uk/whatson/bfi_southbank/events/rupert_bear_night |date=February 20, 2008 }}</ref>
In his spare time he plays and sings in country-folk-pop group [[Monogram]]<ref>[http://www.monogramophone.com/index.html Monogram homepage - a chamber folk music hall art pop group based in Muswell Hill, London - featuring Corinna reicher, Vic Pratt and Stephen McConnachie]</ref> with [[Stephen McConnachie]] and [[Corinna Reicher]] they first performed live at [[The Drill Hall]], London in October 2004 and they recorded their first album for the [[Irregular Records]] subsidiary label for new bands, Unlabelled. He also played and sang in humorous music hall novelty-pop group Dylan Rabbit.<ref>Full name is ''The Dylan Rabbit Pop Circus Orchestra'' https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QJ1OBad2iSk</ref>
He has also played the leading roles in the Hounslow films of director Jan Manthey<ref>[http://kinokarno.tripod.com/id9.html Filmography] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518001403/http://kinokarno.tripod.com/id9.html |date=May 18, 2008 }}</ref> He has acted in films such as ''[[Teenagecstasy]]''.<ref>[http://kinokarno.tripod.com/id2.html Teenage Ecstasy] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704025757/http://kinokarno.tripod.com/id2.html |date=July 4, 2008 }}</ref>
He sent a drawing of himself to [[Robert Crumb]] asking him to draw himself shaking Vic's hand. The art can be seen in the 1974 comic book [[American Splendor|''Odds & Ends'']].<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Odds-Ends-R-Crumb/dp/1582341362 Amazon.com: Odds & Ends: Books: R. Crumb]</ref>
